channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Wintry weather hits travel and power
item.description: Snow, sleet and rain have disrupted transport and left thousands without power as wintry weather continues.

item.title: Buyer found for Blockbuster stores
item.description: DVD and games rental chain Blockbuster has been sold to restructuring specialists Gordon Brothers Europe, its administrators have said.

item.title: Pope Francis meets his predecessor
item.description: Newly elected Pope Francis meets his predecessor for lunch, the first time such a meeting has been possible for more than 600 years.

item.title: France says militant Abou Zeid dead
item.description: The French presidency confirms "with certainty" reports that Islamist commander Abdelhamid Abou Zeid was killed in fighting in Mali in late February.

item.title: 'Significant progress' in Cyprus
item.description: Cypriot Finance Minister Michael Sarris says there has been "significant progress" in talks with the EU and IMF aimed at securing a 10bn-euro bailout.

item.title: UK facing lost decade, Labour says
item.description: The UK risks sliding into a "lost decade" because of the government's failure to get the economy back on track, Labour's leader says.

item.title: UKIP 'only Westminster alternative'
item.description: Voters are turning to the UK Independence Party as it is the only party with alternative policies, its leader Nigel Farage has told activists.

item.title: Cash row student dispute 'resolved'
item.description: An Oxford University college will review its admission policies after ending a financial dispute with an applicant from Salford.

item.title: Salmond focus on independence case
item.description: SNP leader Alex Salmond will further his case for Scottish independence at his party's conference, days after announcing the date of the referendum.

item.title: Bomb found in car in Fermanagh
item.description: A bomb found in a car in County Fermanagh was probably destined for a police station in the area, the Police Service of Northern Ireland say.

item.title: Syria charities appeal raises £3.4m
item.description: A UK aid appeal to help people affected by the two-year conflict in Syria has raised £3.4m in just two days, the Disasters Emergency Committee announces.

item.title: Obama visits ancient ruins of Petra
item.description: US President Barack Obama is ending his visit to the Middle East with a trip to the famous ancient ruins of Petra in Jordan.

item.title: Woman 'dead for 45 minutes' recovers
item.description: A 63-year-old woman who survived a heart attack that left her effectively dead for 45 minutes is recovering well, say medics.

item.title: Artists in secret postcard sale
item.description: Art lovers have been queuing for days to be in with a chance to buy artworks by some of the country's top creative names for £45 each.

item.title: My Chemical Romance announce split
item.description: The US rock group announce their break-up after 12 years together.

item.title: Customers safe, say Cyprus UK banks
item.description: Cypriot banks operating in the UK have insisted their customers will not be affected by any bailout deal.

item.title: Tourists' health cover 'confusion'
item.description: British holidaymakers are confused about the medical cover they can expect if they travel abroad, according to a survey by an insurance body.

item.title: A 'Yes Scotland' should ban Trident
item.description: Delegates at the SNP conference give their backing for the constitution of an independent Scotland to include a ban on nuclear weapons.

item.title: Jones: No U-turn over NHS reforms
item.description: The biggest threat to the NHS in Wales is doing nothing, the first minister tells the Welsh Labour conference.

item.title: Warning over 'struggling GP system'
item.description: Patients in England do not feel safe relying on GP out-of-hours care and are struggling to get access to doctors during normal hours, a leading patient group is warning.

item.title: '570 children a day' start smoking
item.description: More than 200,000 11 to 15-year-olds take up smoking every year in the UK, a charity warns.

item.title: Boys 'suffer from low body image'
item.description: Boys increasingly have low self-esteem about their body image, teachers warn.

item.title: Let children get bored, says expert
item.description: An education expert says children should be allowed to get bored so they can develop their innate ability to be creative.

item.title: Blizzard reveals trading card game
item.description: Blizzard has taken the wraps off the new title it has been developing - a collectable card game based around its Warcraft world.

item.title: Microsoft details data snoopers
item.description: US law enforcement agencies top the list of police forces requesting detailed data about Microsoft users, a report shows.

item.title: Dinosaur-killing rock 'was a comet'
item.description: The space rock that hit Earth 65 million years ago, widely implicated in killing off the dinosaurs, was probably a fast-moving comet, researchers say.

item.title: Advert turns air into drinking water
item.description: A billboard that draws humidity from the air in a rain-starved part of Peru delivers 96 litres of water a day - and has become a local attraction.

item.title: Madness perform TV Centre concert
item.description: Madness have brought the curtain down on BBC Television Centre with a concert outside the iconic building on Friday night.

item.title: Nigerian author Chinua Achebe dies
item.description: Nigerian author Chinua Achebe, regarded as the founding father of African literature, has died after brief illness.

item.title: Why does Game of Thrones inspire such devotion among fans?
item.description: US TV show Game of Thrones has a cult following. But the behaviour of fans is almost as intriguing as the action on screen.

item.title: Quiz of the week's news
item.description: The Magazine's weekly quiz of the news, 7 days 7 questions.

item.title: Snow hits football, rugby & racing
item.description: Northern Ireland v Russia off, along with fixtures in League One and League Two, plus racing at Doncaster and Newbury.

item.title: Finn shines but England face battle
item.description: Steven Finn takes 6-125 but England's batsmen struggle as New Zealand continue to dominate the final Test in Auckland.

item.title: Vettel takes pole in wet Sepang
item.description: Red Bull's Sebastian Vettel beat the Ferrari drivers to take pole position in rain-affected qualifying for the Malaysian GP.

item.title: Robson loses marathon Miami match
item.description: Laura Robson loses to Alize Cornet in the second round of the Miami Masters and misses the chance to become British number one.

item.title: NI v Russia match postponed again
item.description: Northern Ireland's postponed World Cup qualifier against Russia is likely to be rescheduled for June.

item.title: Barbados rapes: MP warns travellers
item.description: An MP calls on the Foreign Office to warn travellers Barbados is "not a safe place" until the local police properly investigate the rape of two British women.

item.title: Hit-and-run death accused in court
item.description: A 58-year-old man from Kent appears in court charged with the hit-and-run death of a 16-year-old moped rider in Dorset.

item.title: Heavy snow disrupts roads and power
item.description: Heavy snow causes major disruption to travel around Scotland while thousands are left without power with cold weather set to continue.

item.title: Man sought over bookmaker robbery
item.description: Strathclyde Police are hunting a man who brandished a firearm during a robbery at a bookmakers in Glasgow.

item.title: Thousands lose power in snow storms
item.description: About 35,000 homes are still without electricity and about 1,000 customers are without water in Northern Ireland after 24 hours of severe weather.

item.title: NI roads closed because of weather
item.description: DIGIONLY

item.title: 6,000 without power after heavy snow
item.description: About 6,000 homes in north Wales are without power after another night of heavy snow, with repairs being hampered by the conditions and road closures.

item.title: Landmarks going dark for Earth Hour
item.description: Some of Wales' landmarks will be plunged into darkness for an hour later as part of the World Wildlife Fund's (WWF) Earth Hour on Saturday.

item.title: DR Congo's Ntaganda in ICC custody
item.description: Congolese war crimes suspect Bosco Ntaganda arrives in The Hague from Rwanda and is in the custody of the International Criminal Court.

item.title: CAR forces 'halt rebel advance'
item.description: Government forces in the Central African Republic (CAR) say they have halted an advance by insurgents towards the capital, Bangui.

item.title: Abu Sayyaf release Australia hostage
item.description: Warren Rodwell, an Australian man kidnapped 15 months ago by an al-Qaeda-linked group in the Philippines, is released.

item.title: China leader Xi hails Russia ties
item.description: Chinese leader Xi Jinping says friendship with Russia guarantees a global strategic balance, on the second day of his trip to Moscow.

item.title: Gunmen free prisoners at Greek jail
item.description: Eleven inmates are missing and two guards injured after gunmen attack a Greek prison, less than a week after a hostage siege at a different jail.

item.title: Croatia beat Serbia in grudge game
item.description: Croatia defeat their fierce rivals Serbia in a football World Cup qualifier, played under heavy security in a hostile atmosphere.

item.title: Charges over Brazil nightclub fire
item.description: Police in Brazil say 16 people will be prosecuted over a nightclub fire in the town of Santa Maria in January, which left 241 people dead.

item.title: Rio indigenous protesters evicted
item.description: Brazilian police evict a group of indigenous protesters from a building they had occupied near Rio de Janeiro's Maracana football stadium.

item.title: Israeli apology for flotilla deaths
item.description: Israel apologises to Turkey for any errors that resulted in the deaths of nine activists during the raid on a flotilla bound for Gaza in 2010.

item.title: Egypt activists clash with Islamists
item.description: Opposition protesters in Egypt clash with Muslim Brotherhood supporters in several towns, ransacking and setting ablaze the Islamist movement's offices.

item.title: Possible suspect in Colorado killing
item.description: Officials are investigating if a gunman who died after a shootout with Texas police on Thursday is linked to a Colorado prison chief's murder.

item.title: Bogus pilot caught in US jet cockpit
item.description: A Frenchman has been charged with impersonating a pilot after he was found in the cockpit of a plane due to take off in Philadelphia, police say.

item.title: Day in pictures: 22 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 22 March

item.title: In pictures: Lives in limbo on India-Bangladesh border
item.description: Alakananda Nag explores the India-Bangladesh border

item.title: In Pictures: Ecology photo contest's winners
item.description: A stunning display of nature's diversity

item.title: In pictures: Obama in Israel
item.description: Obama's first visit to Israel as president

item.title: Day in pictures: 21 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news: 21 March 2013

item.title: In pictures: Car bombs bring chaos to Baghdad
item.description: Aftermath of a series of explosions in Iraqi capital

item.title: In pictures: Sony World Photography Awards
item.description: Winners of the Open, 3D and Youth categories

item.title: In Pictures: The career of Frank Thornton
item.description: A look at the career of the Are You Being Served?

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: George Osborne cuts growth forecasts, corporation tax, and tax on beer.

item.title: VIDEO: Aerial video shows cars buried in snow
item.description: Aerial footage shows cars, trucks and vans completely buried under snow drifts in Cumbria, after blizzard conditions on Friday and overnight into Saturday.

item.title: AUDIO: Would you hire a 'fake girlfriend'?
item.description: A proliferation of websites has appeared offering men the chance to buy a 'fake' girlfriend.

item.title: VIDEO: Scenes of snow and disruption in UK
item.description: Snow, sleet and rain have disrupted transport and power supplies as wintry weather continues in much of the UK.

item.title: VIDEO: Pope Francis meets his predecessor
item.description: Newly elected Pope Francis has met his predecessor for lunch, the first time such a meeting has been possible for more than 600 years.

item.title: VIDEO: Tackling fire in Amazon rain forest
item.description: British firefighter Neil Fairhall travels to Brazil's Mato Grosso state to find out how the local fire brigade deals with blazes in an area of rain forest the size of England.

item.title: VIDEO: Madness perform TV Centre concert
item.description: Madness brought the curtain down on BBC Television Centre with a concert outside the iconic building on Friday.

item.title: VIDEO: Space memorabilia to be auctioned
item.description: A collection of rare space memorabilia, including valuable notes from the Apollo 11 and Apollo 13 missions to the moon, is to go on sale in New York.

item.title: VIDEO: The Cornish kick-boxing dynasty
item.description: The woman who first went to a kick-boxing class in an effort to work off some baby-weight is about to hang up her gloves, a 14-time World Champion.

item.title: Ten good years for Irbil
item.description: The city that spells good times for Iraq's Kurds

item.title: Week in pictures: 16-22 March 2013
item.description: A selection of the best pictures from this week's news

item.title: Did David Bowie change attitudes?
item.description: Did David Bowie change attitudes to sexuality?

item.title: East London artist goes to Hollywood
item.description: Why artist Charming Baker is making a name for himself in LA

item.title: Tips on coping with extreme weather
item.description: Coping with the cold, the Sir Ranulph Fiennes way

item.title: What is the secret of UKIP's appeal?
item.description: Fans and critics - including its founder - on the party's appeal

item.title: San Marino give Hodgson a free ride
item.description: San Marino give Hodgson a free ride, says Phil McNulty

item.title: What if Africa were to become the hub for global science?
item.description: Potential for world-class science in sub-Saharan Africa

item.title: Obama's Long Game in the Middle East
item.description: Mark Mardell on Obama's Middle East ambition

item.title: Is Cyprus small enough?
item.description: How small is too small to matter, asks Stephanie Flanders
